fields.label_text:
CHAIR
ENGLISH; about 1851
Oak with inlaid decoration
Designed by the architect William White (1825-1900) for the Bishop's Palace in Saint Colomb Major, Cornwall (about 1850).
The tough geometrical originality of this chair anticipates the Reformed Gothic style of the 1860's.

The highly original structure of this chair is typical of the Reformed Gothic woodwork that White designed for his churches and country houses at this early stage in his career. Chairs of this design were part of the furnishings of the Bishop's Palace in St Columb Major in Cornwall which White designed in 1850.

fields.descriptive_line: Chair, oak inlaid with walnut, mahogany and ebony, leather seat cover and brass nails; designed by William White for the Rectory, St. Columb Major, Cornwall, British c. 1850
fields.dimensions: Width: 41.5 cm, Height: 47 cm seat only, Depth: 58.5 cm, Height: 90.5 cm
fields.materials_techniques: oak, inlaid with walnut, mahogany and ebony; leather seat cover with brass nails
fields.label:
CHAIR
ENGLISH; about 1851
Oak with inlaid decoration
Designed by the architect William White (1825-1900) for the Bishop's Palace in Saint Colomb Major, Cornwall (about 1850).
The tough geometrical originality of this chair anticipates the Reformed Gothic style of the 1860's. [pre July 2001]
The highly original structure of this chair is typical of the Reformed Gothic woodwork that White designed for his churches and country houses at this early stage in his career. Chairs of this design were part of the furnishings of the Bishop's Palace in St Columb Major in Cornwall which White designed in 1850. [1993]
fields.public_access_description: This chair is an example of the Gothic Revival style of the early 1850s.  The use of plain oak,  with chamfers around the back and stumpy columns for the legs and stretchers, show that the designer, William White (1825-1900), was inspired by the theories of A.W.N. Pugin, the Gothic architect. White established his architectural practice in Truro, Cornwall, in 1847. In 1849 he was commissioned by Rev. Samuel Edmund Walker, Rector of the parish of St. Columb Major, Cornwall, to replace the existing dilapidated Rectory with a new building. White included such innovations as a fire-proof staircase made of granite in the new Rectory, finished in 1851 and praised as a model of domestic religious architecture in The Ecclesiologist. He used similar geometric designs for the stained glass windows and for the inlaid back of the chair, one of a set he designed for the Rectory.
fields.historical_context_note: William White was commissioned in 1849 by the Rev. Samuel Edmund Walker, Rector of the parish of St. Columb Major, Cornwall, to build a new Rectory which was completed in 1851. Walker intended this building to become the palace for a new bishop of Cornwall and in order to increase the value of his endowment of the living of St. Columb for the bishopric Walker invested in property in Notting Hill, London, commissioning a church from White in 1850.
